Event description: In Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, an INGO team was attacked by the local community while travelling towards a Royingya camp amidst rumours that foreigners travelling to the refugee camps have been spreading COVID-19.

In Mombasa city, health workers reported being intimidated by police officers as they tried to provide services during curfew hours. The government curfew was implemented as part of its efforts to contain the spread of COVID-19.

In Kalwanchikudy town, Manmunai South and Eruvilpattu Divisional Secretariat, Batticaloa district, rioters attacked an ambulance and attempted to disrupt hospital activities over the transportation of patients afflicted with COVID-19.
In Belton city, Missouri state, a man motivated by racist and anti-government beliefs sought to bomb a hospital that is providing critical care during the COVID-19 pandemic. Source: BBC and Time

In Douala  city, an increase in anti-foreigner sentiment in the form of verbal and online harassment, stone throwing, and banging on vehicles occupied by expatriates, has been reported. The violence has been linked to the spread of COVID-19 in Cameroon.

In  Yaoundé city, an increase in anti-foreigner sentiment in the form of verbal and online harassment, stone throwing, and banging on vehicles occupied by expatriates, has been reported. The violence has been linked to the spread of COVID-19 in Cameroon.
Muslims defied and protested against government restrictions on prayer attendance at mosques, imposed to reduce the spread of COVID-19.
In Upemba neighbourhood, Lumumbashi city, Haut-Katanga province, a man of Asian descent was attacked during a riot.

In Ethiopia, an increase in anti-foreigner sentiment in the form of verbal and physical harassment, stone throwing, and discrimination has been reported. The sentiment has been linked to the importation of COVID-19 in Ethiopia.
In Addis Ababa city, foreigners of unidentified origin were reportedly attacked with stones and chased by crowds, on suspicion that they were carrying coronavirus.
In Msambweni town, Kwale county, a mob killed a civilian whom they suspected of having coronavirus.
In Mombasa city, paramilitary police officials used violence to disperse a crowd of people waiting to catch a ferry before the start of curfew. Dozens were injured as a result of the attack.

In Kusada town, Katsina state, youths rioted after police officials prevented them from observing their prayers in compliance with measures implemented by the government as part of its efforts to contain the spread of COVID-19.
In Rwanda, reports circulated that two civilians shot dead by police officers were killed for defying the new lockdown measures. The reports were denied by the Rwandan police.
In Johannesburg city, police officials used violence against homeless people minutes after South Africa’s three-week lockdown began.
In Alexandra township, Johannesburg city, military officials raided a large workers’ hostel in the Alexandra township where some residents had defied the lockdown.
In Morogoro city and region, an increase in anti-foreigner sentiment in the form of verbal harassment has been reported. The harassment is linked to the spread of COVID-19 in Tanzania.
In Nampirika village, Iganga district, a mob attacked a Kenyan trader, accusing him of importing COVID-19 after he developed symptoms. The man managed to escape to a police station.
In Bhabdia village, Rajbari Sadar sub district, a man was killed, and 10 others injured in a clash between two groups after arguments over coronavirus.

In Odessa, Ukraine, people repeatedly blocked roads for minibuses and other public transportation in Odessa in demonstration against social distancing measures to counter the spread of coronavirus COVID-19. Cases of violence were also reported.
In Santo Domingo, Valparaiso region, a group of citizens built and set fire to road barricades to restrict tourist access to the district.
In Sampues municipality, Sucre department, around 70 people burned tires in a road to demand from the national government supplies and goods to stay in quarantine because of the coronavirus pandemic.
In Herat city and province, 38 patients who had tested positive for COVID-19 at  Shaidahe Hospital attacked staff and ran away for fear of being quarantined.

In Tejgaon area, Dhaka city and division, more than a hundred residents protested violently against the building of an emergency hospital to cater for COVID-19 patients in the area. The demonstrators vandalized the construction site and attacked construction workers. The protest resulted in the postponement of the project.

From anonymous letters to blatant shunning, nurses and other health workers in France say they are becoming targets of suspicion and even harassment by neighbours and patients fearful of catching Covid-19.

In Tatt Patti Bakhal area, Indore city, Madhya Pradesh state, two female doctors were injured after healthcare workers and civic officials were attacked by a mob while screening residents for coronavirus.
In Hyderabad city, Deccan region, Telangana state, two COVID-19 patients at Gandhi Hospital assaulted a junior doctor after their sibling died from the virus.

Along the Mumbai-Pune highway, near Pune city, Maharashtra state, an ambulance driver reportedly died in an alleged fatal assault by police officials, apparently for ferrying passengers illegally in his vehicle during the lockdown.
In Telangana state, a female doctor travelling to work was assaulted by police officials and forcibly dragged to a police station.

In Munger town and district, Bihar state, a COVID-19 medical response team protected by police officials was attacked by residents when they visited a locality to collect samples from people suspected to have contracted the virus.
In India, police officials enforcing the nation-wide lockdown reportedly assaulted a delivery driver carrying medical supplies.

In Surat city and district, Gujarat state, a female doctor working at a hospital that is treating COVID-19 patients was threatened by neighbours that she would face "consequences" if she continued to work.

Across India, In the midst of the Coronavirus outbreak, landlords have been harassing doctors and forcing them out of their rented property for fear that they might have contracted the disease at work.
In Burundi, some humanitarian organizations have been blocked from reaching and providing assistance to people kept in overcrowded and unsanitary COVID-19 quarantine sites.

In Mea Shearim neighbourhood, Jerusalem city and district, a vehicle carrying medics and municipal inspectors was assaulted with stones while traveling to carry out COVID-19 tests in the area. As a result of the attack, a volunteer paramedic received a head injury in the attack and required hospitalization.
In Abidjan city and department, dozens of protestors violently dismantled a COVID-19 testing centre that was under construction, apparently for being too close to a residential area.

On the Coastal Road, Castelverde town, Tripoli district, Tripolitania region, a doctor and a paramedic on their way to a meeting for the Ministry of Justice to discuss the preventive measures against the Coronavirus for the rehabilitation institutions, were killed during an attack by Tarhouna-based Al-Kani militias of Khalifa Haftar's forces. Two other doctors were also injured.

In Tacurong city, Sultant Kudarat province, a nurse working at St. Louis Hospital was attacked with bleach by five agressors while on his way to work, resulting in severe injuries. Apparently, the suspects had mistaken the nurse to have been a COVID-19 patient.

In Welkom city, Free State, two health workers at Bongani Regional Hospital were injured after police officials fired rubber bullets at a group of protestors demonstrating for more affordable public transport.
In Bang Bon neighbourhood, Bangkok city, Central Thailand region, protestors demanded the removal of COVID-19 patients from a local hospital, citing health concerns.
Local residents beat up police forces at several places of Assam over alleged police high-handedness against the public while trying to enforce lockdown to check the spread of coronavirus.

Police forces fired rubber bullets and used whips against hundreds of shoppers that were queuing outside a supermarket in Yeoville (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) to get provisions for the lockdown caused by the coronavirus crisis.

In San Pedro Sula, Cortes, trasnporters and inhabitants blocked roads with burning tires to demand work and food. The demonstrators have been affected by the quarantine ordered by the government to face the coronavirus pandemic.

In Tegucigalpa, a group of people demonstrated to demand food. The rioters, that have suffered a food shortage due to the quarantine ordered by the authorities to prevent the coronavirus pandemic, burned tires and blocked a street.
In Punta del Diablo (Rocha), around 20 residents blocked the city's entrance with their cars, so tourists would not get in. The main goal of this measure was to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

Three police officers whipped women during the enforcement of coronavirus social distancing at the Mitunguu market in Imenti South (Central Imenti, Meru). A journalist who captured the event was also assaulted after refusing to delete the footage.

A large number of people pelted stones at police at Bhawlaguri market (Bongaigaon district, Assam) when the latter tried to enforce a nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus. Police fired in the air to control the mob.

On 28 Mar 2020, locals beat up nine police officers in Baramati town (Pune, Maharashtra), when they were asked to stay at home and abide the coronavirus lockdown. A case was registered against 6 people.
Several vigilantes impersonating police officers beat up residents with sticks and lathis in Market Yard and Kondhwa areas of Pune city (Pune, Maharashtra), trying to impose the coronavirus lockdown.

In Limon (Limon), businesspersons from the tourism sector of the South Caribbean area blocked the route 32, connecting San Jose to Limon, to demand citizens not to travel to those areas to avoid spreadingthe epidemic.

In Cristobal (Colon), rioters burned garbage cans, blocked roads and vandalized businesses at the communities of Alto de Los Lagos and Los Lagos, as they are suffering from hunger because of the quarantine.

A mob lynched and killed a trooper of the Assam Industrial Security Force (AISF) at Sonabarighat area (Cachar district, Assam) over an alleged tussle amid nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus.
Villagers in Rajpura near Sambhal (UP) attacked a villager who had returned from Delhi suspecting he had coronavirus.

Muslim youth demonstrated violently against the arrest of an Imam in Kusada (Kusada LGA, Katsina). The Imam ignored the Governments restriction on religious gatherings due to coronavirus and was arrested by Police forces.

Quarantined coronavirus patients broke furniture and window panes and demonstrated at a hospital in Srinagar city (J&K) over poor medical facilities. 26 suspect patients jumped the quarantine during the demonstration.

Clashes occurred in Wad Hadramawt (Sayun, Hadramawt) between qat dealers and police forces over the attempt of the police to shut down the qat market due to concerns over coronavirus. A police vehicle was shot at.
Residents reportedly staged a violent demonstration in Zinder, against measures imposed amid the coronavirus pandemic, including the closure of mosques and prohibition of group prayers.

In Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, villagers blocked the entrance to the city. The rioters demanded that the authorities control the entrance because they fear that they may be more exposed to the coronavirus if anyone can enter the city.

The police dispersed Muslim worshippers with tear gas in Awaridi (Diffa, Diffa) for not respecting preventive measures imposed amid the coronavirus crisis. Huts were also burned and four people arrested. No casualties reported.
A boda boda driver was fatally wounded by police near the Kosele trading centre in Rachuonyo (Kasipul, Homa Bay) during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew.
At least five people were reportedly injured by police in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) during the national coronavirus curfew.

Tharu tribals in 50 villages in Pashchim Champaran district (Bihar) blocked the exit and entry points of their villages with nets and bushes to prevent outsiders from coming in and spreading the coronavirus.
A mob of around 300 people beat up two police personnel causing injuries at Falimari market (Dhubri district, Assam) when the latter tried to enforce the lockdown to check the spread of coronavirus.

A boy died after being beaten and chased by local police in Kotli town (Kotli, AJK). Police beat him when he did not stop during the lockdown due to coronavirus, he was trying to save himself and fell in a ditch.

In Pendik district, Istanbul city and province, Marmara region, an unidentified perpetrator stopped an ambulance that was en route to hospital, and questioned the crew on the identity of the patient, and whether or not the patient is infected with Coronavirus. As the crew refused to answer, the perpetrator started throwing punches and followed the ambulance with his car, forcing it to stop. He then proceeded to smash the windows of the ambulance with a cobblestone. Three persons were subsequently detained by security forces in connection with this attack.

In Quetta city and district, Balochistan province, at least 50 doctors protesting the lack of protective equipment provided to health workers while working with COVID-19 patients were arrested. They were later released but they refused to leave the police stations until their demands for more protective equipment were met. The following day, doctors across the province went on strike to protest against the arrests.

In New South Wales state, intensive care nurse at Royal North Shore hospital was assaulted after boarding a train while wearing scrubs, for suspicion of spreading COVID-19. Medical workers are being encouraged not to wear medical outfits in public as a result of increasing hostility.
In New South Wales state, a nurse was verbally harassed at a Coles supermarket, for suspicion of spreading COVID-19.
In Penrith city, Greater Western Sydney region, New South Wales province, a pregnant midwife was verbally abused at a McDonald's drive-through, for suspicion of spreading COVID-19.
In New Zealand, medical staff are increasingly reporting being spat at by members of the public during the lockdown.
In the United Kingdom, nurses and medical staff have reported being harassed by members of the public, including being spat at, called 'disease spreaders', and prohibited from buying food.

At the Arrowe Park Hospital, situated in Upton town, Merseyside metropolitan county, North West England region, a man was arrested for deliberately coughing and spitting in the direction of a nurse working at the Emergency Unit. The man was jailed for six months.

In Canford Heath suburb, Dorset county, South West England, a care home worker was physically assaulted and spat at by a teenager, who accused her of 'having corona'. The worker believes she was targeted because of her nurse uniform.
In Cebu city and province, two men on a motorcycle threw chlorine on a nurse as he made his way home.
Across the Philippines, reports have emerged of health workers evicted from they homes by landlords over fears that the tenants could transmit the virus.
In the Philippines, some nurses have been prevented from leaving their homes by their village captains.
In the United Kingdom, medical staff are being targeted for their identity badges, which can be used to obtain the free food and drinks being offered to NHS workers during the lockdown.
In the UK, reports have emerged of health workers evicted from they homes by landlords over fears that the tenants could transmit the virus.
In Malaysia, reports have emerged of health workers evicted from they homes by landlords over fears that the tenants could transmit the virus.

In Novi Sanzhary town, Novi Sanzhary Raion district, Poltava Oblast province, Ukraining evacuees from China transported in buses into the town in order to be held in quarantine for two weeks were met with violent demonstrators, who attacked the buses with stones and lit bonfires.

In Lviv Oblast province, people used tires and cars to block the entrance to a local hospital because they were afraid the Ukrainian nationals evacuated from China could be brought there and spread the COVID-19 virus.
Near Ternopil city, Ternopil Oblast province, people gathered with a priest on a road to block access to a local medical facility.

In the Central African Republic, a facebook page called "Les dépèches de Bangui" published several posts targeting MSF. The posts alleged that the international organisation benefits financially from the sick, and that vaccines are being used in order to "destroy" rather than to help patients. The page also makes reference to comments made by two French doctors on French television on the possibility of testing COVID-19 vaccines in Africa.

Around 17 March 2020: In Mwanza city and region, a European national working for an INGO was robbed on the street at knife point. This incident occurred within a background of increasing anti-foreigner sentiment, expressed in throat cut gestures, and “corona, go home” yelling towards foreigners.

17 March 2020: In Nairobi city and county, an aid worker was verbally harassed by a local civilian. Reportedly, the civilian referred to the aid worker as 'corona' and told him to return to his country.

02 April 2020: In Kinshasa city and province, a bus transporting French nationals came under attack from residents. The locals, who targeted the bus with stones and shouted insults at those onboard, claimed that the passengers had brought COVID-19 to the DRC.

26 March 2020: In rebel-held areas, Houthi authorities have imposed strict restrictions aimed at halting the spread of Coronavirus, forcing the USAID to partially suspend humanitarian assistance to 70 percent of the Yemeni population. This suspension is believed to leave Yemen vulnerable to contagion. Source: The Washington Times

15 March 2020: The European Commission issued a new regulation that prohibits the export of personal protective equipment to countries outside the EU. As a result, an unnamed supplier has been unable to supply MSF teams around the globe with face masks. Source: Devex

01 April 2020: In Axochiapan city, Morelos state, residents threatened to burn down the Dr. Ángel Ventura Neri general hospital, along with its medical staff, should COVID-19 patients be admitted at the hospital.
09 April 2020: In Reynosa city and municipality, Tamaulipas state, a male trainee doctor was sprayed with bleach by a woman who accused him of spreading COVID-19.
08 April 2020: In Mérida city and municipality, Yucatan state, a female nurse was doused with scalding coffee by a man who accused her of spreading COVID-19.

04 April 2020: In Culiacán city and municipality, Sinaloa state, a female nurse working at a public health clinic was sprayed with bleach on her face by an agressor who was following her home following work.

In Mexico, allegations of rampant discrimination against health workers have been reported, including being denied access to public transport or to supermarkets. As a result, medical workers are being encouraged not to wear their scrubs in public. Special buses are also being provided to health workers.

06 April 2020: In Sabinas Hidalgo city and municipality, a hospital currently under construction was set on fire by unkown men, days after it was announced that it will cater for COVID-19 patients once its construction was completed.

03 April 2020: In San Luis Potosí city and state, a female nurse working at a public hospital was harassed at a convenience shop by children, who threw juice and soda and yelled "Covid!" at her. When the victim scolded the children, she was slapped in the face by their mother. As she attempted to run away, the victim fell and fractured a finger.

11 April 2020: In Shubra al Bahw village, Dakahlia governorate, residents protested against the burial of a female doctor who died of COVID-19, fearing contamination if she was buried at the village cemeteries. The security forces dispersed the residents and arrested 22 demonstrators.

Around 13 March 2020: In Erbil city and governorate, a civilian started to verbally harass health personnel after being asked to have his temperature taken. When police officers arrived to arrest him, he shot and wounded three of them.
In Koy Sanjaq town, Erbil governorate, a civilian visited a hospital dedicated to COVID-19 patients, and assaulted health personnel.

In New Dehli, Dehli state, two female resident doctors at Safdarjung hospital were physically assaulted by a local resident when they tried to reason with him after he told them to stay away from a food stall, for fear of spreading COVID-19.
In Sydney, New South Wales, a nurse who had just finished her shift at an aged care home was coughed upon, verbally abused, and physically assaulted by an elderly woman while ordering food at a shop.
In Meerut city and district, Uttar Pradesh state, a team of medical professionals trying to take a civilian infected with COVID-19 to hospital for treatment came under attack from residents.
On 4 April 2020 (or around), the security forces (assumed police forces) beat up several violators of the coronavirus related curfew in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime).

Reported on April 4, 2020, a police officer caned several teenagers, who were caught for defying the Movement Control Order (MCO) in Kunak, Sabah. Since March 18, 2020, the Malaysian government has been enforcing MCO due to COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 4, 2020, a riot broke out in front of a hospital in Losari sub district, Ujung Pandang district, Makassar city, South Sulawesi province. Dozens of people demanded the hospital release their relative's body, who died presumably of COVID-19.

On 4 April 2020, in Puntarenas (Puntarenas), at the exit of the Ferry from the Nicoya Peninsule, protesters blocked the road to halt access from incoming vehicles from the ferry to Puntarenas. The protesters are concerned that these movements could spark coronavirus infections at Puntarenas. [size=no report]

On April 4 2020, locals associated with the Bhim Army pelted stones at the police in Haridwar city (Uttarakhand) after the police had a dispute with members of the Uttarakhand Sanskrit Academy who violated the coronavirus lockdown to distribute masks and sanitizers. [size=no report]

On 4 April 2020 (or around), members of the anti-coronavirus task force (assumed communal militia) in Nguzu Edda (Atikpo South LGA, Ebonyi) shot 3 people who disregarded restrictions on social gatherings. 1 person died and 2 were injured.

On 4 April 2020, approximately 100 Christian Orthodox Romani rallied outside their closed church in the suburb of Agia Varvara in West Athens singing hymns and protesting against the government's restrictions due to the coronavirus. Police was called by nearby residents, arrested 1 individual and opened an investigation for identifying as many protesters as possible, who violated the ban on gatherings. [size=approximately 100]

On 4 April 2020, around Salto del Guaira (Canindeyu), residents of San Blas neighborhood demonstrated and set fire to tires when the news of 10 Paraguayans arriving from Brazil and being placed in a house to spend the quarantine required by the government
On Apr 3 2020, local residents clashed with the police and Rapid Action Force (RAF) personnel in Shibpur town (Howrah district, West Bengal) over the burial of a coronavirus suspect in Howrah city.
As reported on April 3 2020, a police officer attacked and beat 2 women in Sahatwar area of Ballia district (UP) for allegedly violating the lockdown imposed to prevent coronavirus.

On 3 April 2020, in San Salvador (San Salvador), union workers from the SITTOJ, the Union for Workers of the Judicial Branch, blocked the exit of the Institute of Forensic Medicine to prevent ambulances from leaving the institution.

As reported on 3 Apr 2020, villagers in Muhuldih, Gaitadih and other villagers of East Singhbhum district (Jharkhand) began patrolling the entry points of their villages, armed with lathis, bows and other weapons in attempt to prevent people from entering.

On 3 April 2020, Civilian-JTF stormed Damilu mosque in Yola (Yola North LGA, Adamawa), fired warning shots and dispersed worshippers who ignored the coronavirus restrictions. Several people were injured.

On 3 Apr 2020, police assaulted a vegetable vendor in Beed city market (Beed, Maharashtra) for trying to sell produce during the coronavirus lockdown. As a result, vegetable vendors stopped supplying Beed city and the neighboring areas as a protest against police violence and started donating vegetables to people in need.

On 3 April 2020, four cops were attacked by a group of people in Hubballi city (Dharwad, AP) as the police attempted to stop them from gathering for prayers amid the coronavirus lockdown in the country. [size=no report]

On 3 Apr 2020, locals gathered near a burial ground in Karelibaug area of Godhra city (Panchmahal, Gujarat) opposing the burial of a person who died of coronavirus, fearing further spread of the virus. [size=no report]

On 3 Apr 2020, a group of 10 people pelted stones at police in Untadi village (Porbandar, Gujarat), after police told them to go inside their houses during the coronavirus lockdown. A police officer was injured. [size=10]
On 3 Apr 2020, police assaulted sugarcane farmers who tried to enter Bhigvan village in Beed district (Maharashtra) from Ahmednagar during the coronavirus lockdown and return to their villages.

On Apr 3 2020, a group of police personnel allegedly assaulted a doctor at Purana Bazar in Dimapur town (Dimapur district, Manipur) when he was returning home from work amid the nationwide lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus.

On April 3 2020, around 200 locals, who were violating the lockdown imposed to prevent coronavirus, clashed with the police in Kannauj town (UP). Policeman and local intelligence unit personnel injured. 16 arrested. [size=around 200]

As reported on 3 April 2020, in Puntarenas (Puntarenas), members of the Ngobe indigenous group blocked the road which allows access to their territory, known as Bajo Los Indios, to avoid external infection by incoming travelers due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 3 April 2020, a woman was allegedly shot and injured by police when they opened fire to disperse a crowd at a market in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) during enforcement of the ongoing national coronavirus curfew.

On 3 April 2020, in Sangre Grande, Brooklyn Settlement, close to 15 inhabitants demonstrated against the plan to house a number of coronavirus patients in a former elderly home in the neighborhood. Demonstrators burned tires and debris. [size=close to 15]

On 3 April 2020, community members of Apantem (Akuapim South, Eastern) attempted t to lynch 4 men who arrived from Accra over fears they may carry the coronavirus. The District Chief Executive and his team intervened and saved the victims. [size=no report

On 3 April 2020, residents demonstrated in Dubreka town (Coyah, Kindia) after they found out that at least 7 shops were robbed during the first night of coronavirus related curfew. Some demonstrators accused the police patrols of perpetrating these robberies. The police forces intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators who replied with stones. Several demonstrators were reportedly injured. [size=at least several]

On Apr 3 2020, hundreds of demonstrators in Nassriya city used burning tires to block the main road in the city demanding financial compensation to mitigate the effects of the lockdown and curfew due to the lockdown in place to curb the spread of coronavirus. Clashes with security forces who tried to disperse the demonstrators left 1 demonstrator dead and 8 others injured as police forces reportedly used live fire to disperse the demonstration. Also one police officer was reportedly killed after having rocks thrown on him by demonstrators while another was injured by a gunshot fired by demonstrators. [size=hundreds]

On April 2 2020, a number of rioters on Yefet street in the Ajami neighbourhood of Jaffa, set alight a waste container and hurled rocks and bricks. The demonstrators were outraged by the restrictions being imposed by police while enforcing the public health order to fight against the spread of the coronavirus. When firefighters arrived, two of them were lightly injured by the rock-throwing. Israeli Police then detained an Arab Israeli from the area. [size=no report]
On 2 April 2020, scores of youth demonstrated in Ilutitun (Okitipupa LGA, Ondo) over a planned isolation centre for coronavirus patients in the community. [size=scores]

On April 2, 2020, a group of people held a demonstration in front of a cemetery in Romangpolong sub district, Somba Opu district, Gowa regency, South Sulawesi province, rejecting the burial of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) victim in their area. They blockaded the road with woods and burned a tire. The police intervened and arrested five rioters. [size=at least 5]
On 2 April 2020, three people attacked health workers in Sasthamkotta village (Kollam, KL) as they attempted to collect information about a birthday party held during the lockdown [size=5]

On 2 April 2020, dozens of quarantined Uzbek citizens protested at the sanatorium in Darkhan town of Kibray district in Tashkent region against their isolation after mandatory quarantine placement for 14 days upon arriving from Dubai in Tashkent city on 17 March 2020. Protesters demanded the sanatorium medics let them go because their tests came back negative for coronavirus. [size=dozens]

On April 2 2020, locals, who were violating the lockdown imposed to prevent coronavirus, clashed with the police and attacked them in Morna town near Muzaffarnagar (UP). The clash led to 2 policemen being injured. [size=no report]
On April 2 2020, locals, who were violating the lockdown imposed to prevent coronavirus, pelted stones at the police in Aligarh city (UP). 3 arrested. [size=at least 3]

On 2 April 2020, traders blocked the main road at Wandegeya (Kampala), burning wood to prevent traffic passing. The demonstration appears to be in opposition to coronavirus enforcement measures. Police extinguished the fires, but the source does not mention whether they dispersed the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On Apr 2 2020, lockdown violators in various parts of West Bengal attacked and injured at least nine police personnel while enforcing the ongoing lockdown to combat the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 2 April 2020, miraa traders barricaded the Isiolo-Moyale highway in Isiolo town (Isiolo North, Isiolo) with burning tyres and boulders in demonstration over the demolition of their kiosks. A ban has been placed on the sale and transportation of miraa during the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]
On 2 April 2020, local residents protested at Mulleriyawa town (Kolonnawa, Colombo district) over the funeral of a coronavirus infected person which was held at the local crematorium.

On 2 April 2020, a Nomadic guard opened fire against civilians aboard a motorbike at a checkpoint in Gounou Gaya (Mayo-Boneye, Mayo-Kebbi Est) for not complying with security measures imposed amid the coronavirus pandemic. One civilian was killed and two others severely wounded.
On 2 April 2020, a journalist was "severely beaten" by unspecified security forces (presumed to be police) in Mukono (Mukono district), whilst covering coronavirus curfew measures.

On 2 April 2020, Imbonerakure killed two civilians, including a student, in Minyago (Bwambarangwe, Kirundo) for violating the coronavirus quarantine. The civilians, a father and son, had just returned from Tanzania.

On 2 April 2020, in Caltzontzin, Michoacan, a group of informal workers blocked the roads after having been evicted by the police who closed a market following the measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Police officers shot in the air to disperse

On 2 April 2020, an ambulance driver was wounded after being shot by an unidentified assailant in Candelaria, Quezon. The assailant harassed the ambulance driver for parking the ambulance in a residential district and said that the ambulance could be infected with the COVID-19 (coronavirus). The hospital called for justice and decried the attack as an example of discrimination health workers are increasingly facing in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.

On 1 Apr 2020, a group of people held a protest on the banks of Bhogavo River in Surendranagar city (Surendranagar, Gujarat), against the cremation of a dead woman, fearing she had died of coronavirus. [size=no report]

On Apr 1 2020, a group of 1,000 villagers gheraoed the police and civic officials and staged a protest at the Dhapa crematorium in Kolkata city (Kolkata district, West Bengal) against the cremation of a coronavirus victim in the crematorium fearing contamination.
On 1 April 2020, a journalist (and Delta State NUJ chairperson) was beaten by members of the State Task Force while monitoring the coronavirus lockdown in Asaba (Oshimili South LGA, Delta).

On April 1 2020, police forces physically assaulted two Arab Israelis in Jaffa after they broke the emergency laws the government imposed on citizens to curb the spread of the coronavirus epidemic. No injuries were reported.
On 1 April 2020, police officers allegedly broke the limbs of civilians in Mauche (Njoro, Nakuru) when enforcing the national coronavirus curfew.
On 1 April 2020, demonstrators clashed with police forces in Bizerte, as they demanded to prevent the burial of an old woman who died from coronavirus in a local cemetery. [size=no report]

On 1 April 2020, ASHA health workers were attacked by a group of around 100 locals in Bengaluru city (Bengaluru, KN) as they were collecting data about people affected from coronavirus and their travel history. [size=around 100]

On Apr 1 2020, a group of people pelted stones at quick response teams of police personnel at Bhangore area (South 24 Parganas district, West Bengal) when the latter stopped them from gathering while enforcing the protocols to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Police arrested five of them. [size=at least 5]

On Apr 1 2020, a group of people attacked a police team causing injuries to four personnel in the Goaltore area (West Midnapore district, West Bengal) when the latter asked them not to gather at a tea stall while enforcing the protocols to combat the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
On 1 April 2020, hundreds of youth demonstrated in Oke Odo (Epe LGA, Lagos) over the economic hardships due to the coronavirus restriction and the lack of state support. [size=hundreds]

On 1 April 2020, a man succumbed from his injuries after being allegedly beaten up by police in Ukunda (Msambweni, Kwale) during enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police had also used teargas to disperse at least 12 people, including the deceased, at a bar.

On 1 April 2020, a scuffle broke out between community members and police in Isipingo (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) during the enforcement of the national coronavirus lockdown. An Ethiopian national was killed and a local injured. [size=no report]

On 1 Apr 2020, Muslims assaulted police with brickbats and sticks at Ghuriyan village in Ghosi block (Jehanabad, Bihar), while police searched mosques across Bihar to disperse religious gatherings due to the coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 1 Apr 2020, police used mild force to disperse a Muslim group at Jehanabad mosque in Jehanabad city (Jehanabad, Bihar), while they raided mosques across Bihar to disperse religious gatherings due to the coronavirus lockdown

On 1 Apr 2020, Muslims opened fire at police at Andhra Tharai village in Madhubani district (Bihar), while police raided mosques across Bihar to disperse religious gatherings due to the coronavirus lockdown. No injuries and fatalities reported.

On Apr 1 2020, police clashed with locals in the north 24 Parganas district (West Bengal) after residents prevented health workers from collecting coronavirus data. Seven persons were injured when police tried to enforce the lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus.

On 1 April 2020 (or around), a delivery driver for the Vanguard newspaper was beaten up by police officers at the Abia/Akwa Ibom border on the Umuahia-Ikot Ekpene Highway, for allegedly violating the coronavirus restrictions.

On April 1 2020, clashes erupted between Arab citizens and Israeli Police in the Ajami neighbourhood of Jaffa in Tel Aviv as rioters attempted to blocked the areas main road with burning tyres, in demonstration against the violent police actions during the imposition of the coronavirus restrictions, referring to an incident which occurred earlier in the day where Police forces assaulted two citizens after they broke the curfew rule. Police forces used physical violence to break apart rioters, which led to a number of injuries and the detention of 4. Rioters hurled objects and burned tyres, which led to an injury amongst the Police. [size=no report]

On 1 April 2020, residents of President Roxas, Cotabato staged a demonstration in front of a government-run hospital in the same town, barricading the hospital's entrance to oppose the local government's plan to transform it into a COVID-19 (coronavirus)
On 31 Mar 2020, police used lathis and force to disperse an Islamic religious procession at Sarwar town (Ajmer, Rajasthan), enforcing measures of social distancing during the coronavirus lockdown.

On March 31 2020, protesters blocked the Mahmra highway briefly in a demonstration against difficult living conditions amidst the lockdown and tightened security measures in an effort to stop the spread of the coronavirus, and especially for people below the poverty line. [size=no report]

On 31 March 2020, in Linares, Maule region, members of the military forces of Chile opened fire when a civilian attempted to avoid a military checkpoint set to control a national lockdown for coronavirus pandemic. No person was injured in the event.

On March 31, 2020, hundreds of people blockaded a road to a cemetery in the Antang sub district, Manggala district, Makassar city, South Sulawesi province, with chairs. They rejected the burial of a former member of the city council, who died of COVID-19 (Coronavirus). The head of the sub district shouted at the ambulance, saying the bodies of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) could transmit the virus to the locals. [size=hundreds]

On March 31, 2020, a group of people held a peaceful protest in Karangtengah village, Cilongok district, Banyumas city, Central Java province, opposing the burial of a COVID-19 (Coronavirus) victim at the neighbouring village. The next day, the regent of Banyumas dug the grave to show people that the body of COVID-19 (Coronavirus) victim is not transmitting the virus. [size=no report]

On March 31, 2020, a group of Papuans held a protest at a sports complex in Wangirja sub district, Mimika Baru district, Mimika Regency, Papua province, opposing the usage of the sports complex as an isolation place for suspected COVID-19 (Coronavirus) patients. They threatened to burn the complex. The police intervened and dispersed the protest. The leader of the protest was arrested. [size=no report]

On 31 March 2020, Tunisian police forces employed tear gas to disband a protest held by health workers infront the regional hospital in Kasserine, to demand medial equipment and protective measures against contagion with coronavirus. [size=no report]

On March 31, 2020, a group of people peacefully intercepted a burial process of a COVID-19 (Coronavirus) victim in Baru City sub district, East Tanjung Karang district, Bandar Lampung City, Lampung province. The medical team took the body to another cemetery nearby, where they faced the same issue. In the end, the body was buried in a province-owned cemetery. [size=no report]

On March 31, 2020, in the Riohacha-Maicao way, La Guajira department, 20 communities of the Wayuu indigenous people blocked a road to demand water and food. Protesters demanded basic goods due to the preventive mandatory isolation to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On March 31 2020, a young woman was attacked and shot dead by an army personnel in Mainpuri (UP) for preparing a list of all arrivals in the city to prevent the spread of coronavirus, as the list included his name.

On 31 March 2020, police fired upon a boda boda driver in Kampala, after the driver failed to stop at a checkpoint, as part of coronavirus enforcement measures. The driver was wounded in the buttocks. Police have claimed the driver grabbed a police officer, prompting them to shoot him.

On 31 March 2020, a group of residents of the Pole Chudes neighbourhood in Novopavlovka village of Sokuluk district in Chui region blocked the local road in protest after increased traffic through their neighbourhood due to coronavirus quarantine. Protesters complained dishonest car drivers use the road to evade quarantine police roadblocks on a nearby main highway in order to enter Bishkek city without official passes which are mandatorily issued by the authorities. [size=no report]

On 1 April 2020, a group of Mayak village residents protested against the local authorities' plan to open a quarantine facility for possibly infected with coronavirus patients near their village in Tup district of Issyk-Kul region. The local authorities were forced to abandon the plan after demonstrations. [size=no report]

As reported on 31 March 2020, a civilian was severely beaten up by a police officer in Kinshasa (Kinshasa), for what was considered a violation of the coronavirus lockdown imposed by the Congolese government.

On 31 March 2020, LDU paramilitaries beat a journalist and the driver of the boda boda he was travelling with in Makindye (Kampala), and insisted they be paid a bribe to release them. The attack was ostensibly related to coronavirus enforcement measures.

On 31 March 2020, gendarmes entered the Kossodo University area in Ouagadaougou (Kadiogo, Centre), and assaulted students for not complying with the nightly curfew imposed amid the coronavirus pandemic. A large number of students at the campus reacted to what they perceived as abusive and heavy-handed behavior by the gendarmes and barricaded the campus area and clashed with the gendarmes who fled but soon returned with reinforcements and fired teargas to disperse the students. [size=large]
On or after 31 March 2020, security services (presumed to be police) beat an on-duty doctor in northern Kampala for violating the coronavirus lockdown measures introduced on 31 March.

On 31 March 2020, in Olmos, Lambayeque, 30 citizens blocked the highway leading to El Boliche sector, to avoid the entrance of outsiders during the coronavirus pandemic. Police forces tried to removed the group and there was a clash. The citizens threw stones and sticks, that left 10 officers injured, at least one woman was injured and 6 citizens were arrested. [size=30]
On 31 March 2020, 11 people were assaulted by ZRP officers after gathering at bars in Masvingo (Masvingo Metro, Masvingo) during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 31 Mar 2020, police officers beat up the president of an NGO near Gondal Chowkadi in Rajkot city (Rajkot, Gujarat), when the latter was transporting a man's body, who died of old age, to Gondal in an ambulance and was stopped by police during the coronavirus lockdown.

On 31 March 2020, a group of about 300 members of the Muslim community in Agege (Agege LGA, Lagos) pelted stones at a team of the Lagos State Environmental Protection Agency that attempted to enforce the coronavirus lockdown directive in their mosque.

On 31 Mar 2020, a Muslim group pelted stones at police in Gidarganj village under Jhanjharpur sub-division (Madhubani, Bihar), while police raided mosques across Bihar to disperse religious gatherings due to the coronavirus lockdown. Some police officers were injured and two police vehicles were damaged. [size=no report]

On March 30 2020, an armed clash that lasted several hours erupted between Palestinians of the Qalandia refugee camp and residents of Kafr Aqab. Palestinians from Qalandia prevented residents from leaving Kafr Aqab by blocking its entrance, to prevent the spread of the coronavirus as 2 residents had been infected. A resident of Kafr Aqab was seriously injured in the exchange of gunfire and the Palestinian Authority sent a special anti-riot force to break up the confrontations.

On 30 March 2020, in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, about 30 street vendors blocked Miguel Aleman Avenue to demand economic support in view of the drop in income caused by the coronavirus security measures. [size=about 30]

On 30 March 2020, hundreds of demonstrators barricaded routes and burned tires in El Mnihla (Ariana) to demonstrate against delays in promised state welfare assistance for poor families during the coronavirus lockdown. [size=hundreds]
On March 30, 2020, a group of people held a peaceful protest in Depok city, West Java province, opposing the burial of a COVID-19 (Coronavirus) victim in their area. [size=no report]

On 30 Mar 2020, a man was lynched to death by locals in an area under Runni Saidpur police station (Sitamarhi, Bihar), after an argument over sharing information about people who came back from Maharashtra on the government's helpline for coronavirus. Seven people were arrested. [size=no report]
As reported on Mar 30 2020, police assaulted persons violating the lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus at different parts of Arunachal Pradesh, as revealed by video footage.

As reported on Mar 30 2020, police assaulted four migrant workers in Kimin town (Papum Pare district, Arunachal Pradesh) for violating the lockdown order of the government in response to the coronavirus epidemic, as revealed by a video footage.

On 30 March 2020, in Tegucigalpa, several groups of people demonstrated to demand food and water in different neighbourhoods of the city. The demonstrators burned tires to block the streets. The rioters have not received the food promised by the government to keep the curfew ordered to prevent coronavirus transmission.
On 30 March 2020, police and soldiers beat people who did not heed to the 21 day coronavirus lockdown, and forced them to roll on the ground in Maseru (Maseru). No fatalities were reported.

On 30 March 2020, eight people attacked and injured a policeman in Hyderabad city (Hyderabad, TS) as the policeman tried to disperse the group who had gathered despite the ongoing lockdown to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. [size=8]

On 30 March 2020, dozens of members of the religious movement Bundu dia Kongo (BDK) clashed with police forces in Kinshasa (Kinshasa), during an unauthorized march due to coronavirus. It was reported followers were marching to perform mystical rites. Tension started to mount and followers threw stones to police officials, who used teargas and shot in the air to disperse participants. Between 4 and 5 followers were killed and several injured. BDK followers denied violence on their part, and police officials discounted the death toll. [size=dozens]

As reported on 30 March 2020, in Tankuche, Campeche, to protect themselves against the coronavirus, the inhabitants closed the accesses to the community to prevent the passage of any person alien to the population. The road to Halacho was blocked with a tree that was knocked down. [size=no report]

On 30 March 2020, demonstrators barricaded routes and burned tires in Ettadhamen (Mnihla, Ariana) to demonstrate against delay in promised state welfare assisatance for poor families and demand work permits for daily labourers whose sources of income were disrupted during the general coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]
On 30 March 2020, in Merida, Yucatan, for fear of coronavirus infection in their area, demonstrators closed the access to Susula that borders an ISSSTE Hospital Clinic. [size=no report]
On 30 March 2020, three people were assaulted with batons and kicked by ZRP officers in Harare (Harare) during the national coronavirus lockdown.
On 30 March 2020, a young boy was fatally wounded in Huruma, Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) when police used live ammunition during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew.

On 30 Mar 2020, a police officer beat up a municipal clerk on the way to his office in Pune city (Pune, Maharashtra) for an unknown reason during the coronavirus lockdown. The clerk said police did not ask about his reason for going out.

On 30 March 2020, a group of rickshaw pullers and youth demonstrated in Toamasina (Toamasina II, Atsinanana) against the lack of food provisions by the government during coronavirus lockdowns. The demonstrators clashed with police who intervened using tear gas. One journalist was stabbed and injured. [size=no report]

On or around 29 March 2020, police allegedly beat and tasered a man who left his house during the national coronavirus lockdown to buy beer in Ravensmead (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). The man later died from his injuries.

On 29 March 2020, a metro officer and a security officer fatally shot a man in Vosloorus (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) during the national coronavirus lockdown. It is reported that the victim was followed home where he was fatally shot following an earlier clash between rioters and police. The two officers were arrested. The accused also face four attempted murder charges after three children and an adult were injured during the shooting.

On Mar 29 2020, a health worker was attacked and injured by a policeman in Koya district, after the health worker days earlier had transferred the policeman to the hospital to get tested for coronavirus for having a fever. The policeman was later arrested.

On 29 March 2020, members of Asayish anti-terror forces assaulted civilians in the town of Basira in the countryside of Deir-ez-Zor for violating the curfew imposed on the town to limit the spread of Coronavirus.

On March 29, 2020, a group of people held a peaceful protest at Cisapi crematorium in Gununggede sub district, Kawalu district, Tasikmalaya city, West Java province, opposing the cremation of a COVID-19 (Coronavirus) victim in their village. The body had to be taken back to the hospital. [size=no report]

On 29 March 2020, in Arica, Arica y Parinacota region, members of the military forces of Chile opened fire against a private car when the driver attempted to avoid a military checkpoint set to control a national lockdown for coronavirus pandemic. The victim is severely injured in the ICU of the local hospital.
On March 29 2020, locals who were violating the lockdown imposed to prevent coronavirus, clashed with the police and pelted stones at them in Bhadrauli town near Agra (UP). [size=no report]

On 29 March 2020, two soldiers assaulted a street vendor with her baby in Cabinda, under the pretext of compliance with the guidelines under the state of emergency decreed by the Angolan state to contain the coronavirus pandemic.

On 29 March 2020, police officers shot and killed a young man inside a bar in the Tigray region following a proclamation banning public gatherings due to coronavirus. Some reports claim that the young man was drunk and attacked police officers (no weapon)

On 29 March 2020, pro-STC forces, coded as Security Belt forces by default due to the lack of more precise information, reportedly stormed the port of Aden (Al Mansurah, Aden) aboard six military vehicles and looted nine ambulances provided by the WHO amid fears of a coronavirus outbreak in the country. WHO provided a shipment containing 81 ambulances - 12 of which were destined for Aden, 15 mobile medical clinics, and 65 artificial respirators. According to at least one source, the totality of the shipment is being detained by pro-STC gunmen.

On 29 March 2020, in San Pedro Sula, Cortes, demonstrators blocked two different streets using burning tires and tree branches to demand food. The demonstrators have not received the food promised by the government to keep the curfew ordered to prevent coronavirus transmission [size=no report]

As reported on 29 March 2020, Ugandan military intelligence personnel reportedly abducted and tortured at least two Rwandans who had been living in the area of Jinja (Jinja district), ostensibly as part of coronavirus enforcement measures. The source also states that the victims, along with 342 other Rwandans, were then left at the Rwandan border by Ugandan authorities.

On 29 March 2020, in Oruro city, a group of neighbors of the Pumas Andinos human settlement clashed against Police and Military forces. The group was reluctant to follow the quarantine established due to the coronavirus pandemic, and started throwing stones at the officers when they tried to enforce the measure. 73 neighbors, 4 of them underaged, were detained by the officers and were released after 8 hours. [size=at least 73]

On March 29, 2020, the municipal police (zabita) forces of the Uskudar municipality assaulted 3 civilians in Uskudar, Istanbul, allegedly for violating the fishing ban, which is a part of broader security measures taken by the government banning all the recreational activities on the coasts, including fishing, jogging, doing picnics etc. to curb the spread of the coronavirus. The victims who were subject to beating were mildly injured in various parts of their bodies.

On 29 March 2020, a police officer was wounded after being shot by armed assailants in Barangay Damawato, Datu Paglas, Maguindanao. The police officer had flagged the group for violating a curfew in place because of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic.
Admin 3 (Province): Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao

Event description: On Mar 29 2020, workers of two factions of Trinamool clashed and hurled bombs at each other at Ramnagar in Garden Reach in Kolkata city (Kolkata district, West Bengal) over distribution of food to locals stuck at homes due to the lockdown amid coronavirus pandemic. Police arrested seven people in this connection and some people were reportedly injured in the incident. [size=at least 7]
Anti-foreigner hate speech emerged on various social media platforms following the first Covid-19 infections detected in the country, among which was a Dutch United Nations staffer.
